title: Ten Freaky Hoes
review: We're not going to pretend there's anything politically correct about this highly inappropriate song. It is what it is: a G-Funk anthem.

title: Trap Back
review: The message -- slathered on top of rousing production -- is loud and clear: 2 Chainz never left. And he wants his trap back.

title: She Looks So Perfect
review: There’s nothing like seeing your first sweetheart partially disrobed and ready to take your future by storm. The teen anthem of the year.

title: Hearne: Palindrome for Andrew Norman
review: A fascinating ode to a fellow composer, with shards of Bach, Mahler, Ligeti and Kanye (played by an ambitious new ensemble).

artist: A Winged Victory For The Sullen
title: ATOMOS IX
review: Pianist Dustin O'Halloran and composer Adam Wiltzie release the year’s most beautiful song.

title: Dancing To The Radio
review: Danceable and unabashedly hip Mexican disco.

title: Stuck in the South
review: This young Nashville-based hellraiser's first single is an instant sensation about social entrapment and the determination to shake it.

title: Defragment #2
review: L.A. producer Nicholas Crozier Malkin delivers the late-night trip-hop jam of the year. Yes, I just used the phrase "trip-hop" in 2014.

title: Say Yes
review: “Yes” may be the most powerful word in any language. Here, it's a joyful, hand-clapping mantra to live by.

title: Transgender Dysphoria Blues
review: Two years after Laura Jane Grace came out as transgender, this the sound of suppression turned into punk rock triumph.

title: Dura Como Piedra
review: The Puerto Rican rocker keeps his hard edge but never loses his sense of humor.

title: Big Up
review: Alika brings it once again with a reggea-tinged rage against the corruption of the powerful.

title: Left Hand Free
review: Swaggering wordplay and funk guitar so brilliantly produced it leaves you wondering how they did it.

title: Hunger Of The Pine
review: This song of longing and desire, with a sample of Miley Cyrus singing, "I'm a female rebel," is jarring and catchy at the same time.

title: Wash It Down
review: With an opening like a playground rhyme, this sounds like something you've heard before -- until it turns into something else entirely.

title: Archie, Marry Me
review: The Toronto band issues a jangly ode to full-throated, full-hearted commitment.

title: Hard 2 Find
review: On this syrupy trip, Houston native Amber London hearkens back to the mid-to-late ’90s, when rap was in the grips of the South.

title: Our Basement (Ed)
album: The Imagined Savior is Far Easier to Paint
review: Shades of Laura Nyro in this lissome collaboration between singer Becca Stevens and the big-dreaming trumpeter.

title: Lonely Richard
review: The year's rock song mostly likely to play during the end credits of a Richard Linklater film.

title: Vengo
review: A transcendent artist breaking out of hip-hop and Latin music. Her success will be due to her language, not in spite of it.

title: Yield
review: This young producer from Gothenburg, Sweden struck gold on his first official 12". Our disco jam of the year.

title: Love The Way
review: Ashong, a British-Ghanaian soul singer, doesn't waste any words on this sweet, simple and incredibly catchy song.

title: Forgiven/Forgotten
album: Burn Your Fire For No Witness
review: Two blistering minutes on an otherwise wistful album; "Forgiven/Forgotten" is unforgettable.

title: Unfucktheworld
album: Burn Your Fire For No Witness
review: Cold as winter’s bone, glowing like an eternal ember, this timeless take on mountain blues captures the panicked core of heartbreak.

title: minipops 67 [120.2][source field mix]
review: Richard D. James' first official song in 13 years actually lived up to the outrageously high expectations.

title: Break Free
review: Pop's ruling ingenue goes positively glossolalic on the glowstick-waving EDM song of the year.

title: King and Cross
review: Asgeir Trausti Einarsson hasn’t been singing in English for long, but you wouldn’t have guessed.

title: Out of the City
review: Riffs upon riffs upon riffs of classic hard rock by way of Norway (and a puppet-filled video worth seeking out).

title: Bad Day
review: These Australian garage pranksters chant what we all think in our darkest moments of self-pity.

title: Idle Delilah
review: A complicated fairy tale bubbles beneath Banks's boasts as glitchy pan-Caribbean rhythms make waves she can float on.

title: I'm Talkin' Bout
review: Lizard brain bass, itchy snares and creamy synths in distinctly Houstonian proportions under lines about plans foiled and reset.

artist: Bang on a Can All-Stars & Trio Mediaeval
title: Wolfe: Some Say (from 'Steel Hammer')
review: Composer Julia Wolfe reframes Appalachian sounds and the legend of John Henry with the ethereal-voiced Trio Mediaeval.

title: Dirty Cigarettes
album: Cheap Thrills On A Dead End Street
review: A bittersweet, larger-than-life rock song for those who "get in trouble when things get quiet."

title: Morning
review: Meticulous instrumentation, feather-light vocals and melodic hooks make this one of the most lovely, laid back songs of the year.

title: Shotgun Blues
review: Fleck and Washburn turn the murder ballad genre on its head by turning the gun on the man this time, along with a healthy dose of guilt.

title: Venter
album: A U R O R A
review: A trio played on bells, drums and the post-apocalyptic wind that chills the bones of the dead in a barren icescape.

title: Youth
review: Ethereal production and sultry vocal crying for society's attention; the winner by a nose on the London native’s debut EP.

title: Have You Seen My Son
review: Digging out the roots of garage rock, a 22-year-old maverick finds a link between Southern juke joint blues and The Replacements.

title: Come Around With Me
review: Try not to move as the multifaceted Norwegian singer flexes his falsetto on this funk-fueled, yacht-rock jam.

title: Flawless (Remix)
review: This is the sound of pop-driven feminism in 2014: smooth, hard, 100 proof.

title: Mt. Olympus
review: The Mississippi mainstay spits balls of flame, fury and frustration on this monster of a track.

title: The Towns We Love is Our Town
review: Thanks to songs like this, Brooklyn pianist David Moorebecame the ambient darling of the electronic music world in 2014.

title: Soul Of A Woman
review: A laid-back groove, the distant crackle of spinning vinyl and BJ's voice, supple as ever, in this tribute to a woman's beauty.

title: Hot -----
review: You'll never be able to say "about a week ago" again without wanting to toss up your hat and hit the Shmoney Dance.

title: Ark.La.Tex
review: When he's not gigging on his day job with Wayne Shorter, drummer Brian Blade leads his Fellowship through the far reaches of jazz.

title: Class Historian
album: Just Enough Hip To Be Woman
review: One of the year’s most ridiculously catchy songs.

title: Asi De Grande Son Las Ideas
review: Calle 13 continues to deftly combine art and message in this musically adventurous track.

title: Dip----s
review: That rare one-to-one match of music and lyric, concrete jungle winner’s circle swagger personified.

title: Bernstein: Candide Overture
album: If You Could Read My Mind
review: Carpenter pulls out all the stops on his tricked out organ, animating Berrnstein’s Overture with a kaleidoscope of chirps, blurps and bells.

title: Our Love
review: The title track to Dan Snaith's latest album sounds natural on both indie-rock playlists and the dance floor -- not a small feat.

title: Scott Get The Van, I'm Moving
review: It's been a helluva year for the Philly punk scene. Cayetana's an anxious lot, it swings for the fences every damn time.

title: Cuando Te Tenga
review:
Bastida wears her heart on her sleeve in this expectant
but ominous song about her hopes and fears as a mother-to-be.

artist: Chance The Rapper & The Social Experiment
title: Wonderful Everyday: Arthur
review: With help from a soaring band, Chance gifts us with a revival of a childhood theme song we never knew we needed.

title: Boom Clap
review: The Top 40 equivalent of a bedazzled Trapper Keeper sharpie'd with arrow-struck red hearts.
Warm, sexy, nonchalant and always in the groove.

title: Cerveza
review: The Texan rapper shows up at your doorstep with great beats ... and fajitas.

title: New Flame
review: Two of R&B's high-energy performers slow it down for a feel-good confection of a jam about new possibilities in love.

title: Dark Side Of The Moon
review: A tear-jerker ode to fatherhood that leaves you feeling grateful for every precious moment of your stupid little life.

title: Real Love
review: Bewitching murmurs from the Wild Colonials vocalist enhance this chill-out room seduction by the twin-brother team known for its work with Drake and J. Cole.

title: Hot 97 Summer Jam
review: The pangs of the summer crush, translated into this perfect pop-punk bummer that borrows from doo-wop: "Does she love you like I love you?"

title: Fears Away
review: Perfect band name, even better music. This track floats right into your conciousness.

title: Rather Be
review: A bubblicious bit of electro-pop that offered some needed sweetness in a heavy year.

title: Hundreds of Ways
review: Amid buoyant horns and crisp West African guitar lines, Oberst mulls over celebrity, aging and violence that threatens to dismantle society, yet remains hopeful.

title: Kyr: Transcending: And Love Remains
album: The Cloud of Unknowing / Songs of the Soul
review: Born in the silence of a New Mexico desert, Kyr’s music resounds with a gleaming, transcendent ecstasy.

title: Honorable (feat. Raekwon)
review: The direct sunlight clarity of a Large Professor beat matched with Raekwon's believable bluster and Cormega's sinewy hindsight.

title: Silver Timothy
album: Brothers and Sisters of the Eternal Son
review: Jurado's inspired pairing with producer Richard Swift pairs the former's hushed narratives with psychedelic echo and Latin percussion.

title: My Favourite Faded Fantasy
review: The Irish singer returns after nearly a decade-long hiatus and just crushes it. A breathtaking, monstrous record of epic beauty.

title: Sonderho Bridal Trilogy Pt. II
review: The superb quartet takes a break from Beethoven to explore its Nordic roots -- like this buoyant tune that’s been danced at Danish weddings for some 400 years.

title: Sue (Or In A Season Of Crime)
review: Borrowing a bit of Scott Walker’s macabre majesty, Bowie gets epic post-industrial jazz courtesy of the Maria Schneider Orchestra.

title: Caminante Caminando
review: A new artist to take notice of, as this ode to immigrants superbly illustrates.

title: The Secret
review: One of country’s most sensitive and powerful young vocalists scales the heights on this intriguing ballad about lost love and cruel realities no one can admit.

title: Ilsa Drown
review: Jonsi pops up to lend some of his otherworldly "fyooooo" sounds to this lovely, muted and moody folk ballad.

title: Paradise Girls
review: Riff rock akin to being led through a raging party by a cheerful narrator. In other words, Deerhoof doing what it does best.

title: F For You (feat. Mary J. Blige)
review: News of this collaboration blew people's minds. Looking back, we should have seen it for what it was: a natural fit.

title: Pet Sematary
review: Predictably gorgeous, deservedly jaundiced and wholly unfair to the competition.

title: Going Down To The River
review: After years spent on the street, a gifted singer-songwriter shares the gospel of redemption.

title: Grand Canyon
review: It’s almost unbearable to lose someone you love; this elegy for a member of the veteran Southern band’s family nods to the difficulty of letting go while providing a way to do it.

title: Meadow Mines (Fort Polio)
review: Lo-fi San Francisco singer-songwriter channels the melodic psych-folk meanderings of Syd Barrett.

title: Drone Transitions
review: This Sydney singer released the drone track of 2014 using only her voice. A transcendental experience that fans of La Monte Young will love.

title: So Blonde
review: It sounds like the ‘90s, but embedded with self-awareness: its lyric, about being seduced by rock and the sexy kids who make it, critiques the very desire the sound stimulates.

title: DBF
review: Legendary sound wizard Brian Eno and Underworld guitarist Karl Hyde, update the Talking Heads’ New Wave take on the African diaspora, even more nervous and propulsive for the new century.

title: Give Me Back My Hometown
review: Love and loss at the Pizza Hut: this country heart-stomper provides perfect insight into small-town pride

title: Don't Wanna Lose
review: Mary Timony's new band distills decades of punk, rock and glam into a perfect little two-and-a-half-minute laser beam of joy.

title: How You Say (Redux)
review: One of dance music's few great bands revisits and re-energizes a deep track from its 2013 album.

title: Bored In The USA
review: A horribly cynical but perfectly appropriate anthem to close out another brutal year of soul-crushing headlines.

title: The Liar
review: The Austrian avant artist processes the bejesus out of his guitar on this harrowing beacon of a track.

title: Shattered & Hollow
review: The Swedish sister act opens with a doozy of a confession -- "I am in love and I am lost" -- before launching into a gorgeous defense of boldness and risk.

title: Two Weeks
review: The music wobbles unsteadily, shrouded in smoke. But the voice couldn't be surer in its libidinous, hungry intent.

title: King Bromeliad
review: Arguably the leftfield track of the year, this feels like showing up for a basement dance party and finding an in-its-prime Funkadelic.

title: Never Catch Me
review: L.A.'s finest team up for four minutes of making the impossible seem effortless. Bonus: the music video of the year.

artist: Freddie Gibbs & Madlib feat. BJ the Chicago Kid
title: Shame
review: Cold conquest as told by one of our most adroit rappers over a beat by one of our more ambivalent producers, with a hook sung by the warmest voice in R&B.

title: Benz Friendz (Whatchutola)
review: Anti-materialist rant, mystical freaky-Atlanta chant.

title: Seasons (Waiting On You)
review: Samuel Herring’s sincere croon and killer dance moves propelled this hard-working, life-affirming band into a new stratosphere.

title: For You
review: Paul Dixon, a British experimental musician, flirts with rhythm & blues on this heart-palpitating journey through the trials of commitment.

title: Empire Liquor Mart (9127 S. Figueroa St.)
review: A 15-year-old girl is shot dead in an L.A. liquor store. This is her story, crafted into a brilliant but heartrending mini-opera.

title: Michael
review: Christopher Barnes' fragile singing sets the tenuous tone for this tale of a "cautious man" filled with love for another man.

title: Miles De Millas
review: A vocie that commands attention, lyrics even more.

title: Sememen
review: What if Chopin had vacationed in Addis Ababa? In this alluring piano music, poetic filigree meets spirited Ethiopian sounds.

title: New Dark Ages
album: A World Lit Only by Fire
review: Godflesh is back. Watch the world burn.

title: CNTRL
review: The beat is intentionally touch and go, but rapper GoldLink stays the course as he skips through it with a song in his heart.

title: GF Jeans
review: Funky discombobulations and titillating, heart-pounding desire.

title: Yours To Shake
review: Roots rock that questions whether we’re inherently good or evil, with a killer and memorable guitar groove.

title: Clearing
review: Ingredients as spare as they come -- a piano, Liz Harris' narcotic voice -- but a tone that's drowsily enveloping to the point of suffocation.

title: Joker
review: The Brazilian producer gives us EDM's equivalent to The Alan Parsons Project's "Sirius," and it's kind of perfect.

title: Defenestration Song
review: Six years after a bleak debut that's since found a cult-ish following, Have A Nice Life returned with a pitch-black, post-punk party-rocker.

title: Full Stick
review: A perfect rock 'n' roll summer jam in 100 seconds, and it still finds time for a guitar solo.

title: I Will Run
review: With a sing-along chorus wrapped in an off-centered picking pattern like a warped 45 finding its groove, this heavy-metal ballad will break your heart.

title: Since Last Wednesday
review: A bright sound for a dark subject: A missing friend, incidents of vandalism and a gun gets you thinking about the people we think we know and care about.

title: Saturday's Song
review: A standout track from The Lateness of Dancers, my favorite album of the year.

title: I Miss Your Bones
review: A perfect expression of desire and longing wrapped up into a simple and loving refrain.

title: Jackie and Wilson
review: A red-eyed fantasy set to blue-eyed soul and a killer back beat.

title: Take Me To Church
review: The pulpit and the bedroom inch ever closer together.

title: Chimes
review: What it lacks in originality, it more than makes up for in technical prowess. Nothing sounded better at top volume in 2014.

title: Down From The Rafters
album: The Moon Rang Like a Bell
review: As the music heaves and creaks like a boat trapped in ice, Nicole Miglis whispers sweet anxieties.

title: The Body Electric
review: Alynda Lee Segarra isn’t the first woman to notice that folk music killed a lot of women, but she’s the one who intervened. One of the most potent political songs of the year.

title: River
review: Twin 19-year-old sisters draw upon electronica and their Afro-Cuban Yoruban heritage in equal measure. Mesmerizing.

title: Club Goin' Up On A Tuesday
review: The spirit of weird Atlanta flows through this young MC.

title: Dernière Danse
review: A new artist blends smoky storytelling with gigantic pop hooks. 151 million YouTube hits and counting.

title: Girls Chase Boys
review: The smartest, coolest, most irresistible pop kiss-off of the year.

title: Be Free
review: A stunning, raw response to the national crisis that’s arisen after the killing of Michael Brown in Ferguson, Missouri, this song from North Carolina rapper Cole is this year's "Strange Fruit."

title: Kingdom (Les Chênes, Les Bouleaux)
review: Hovering above the fringes of classical and ambient music, “Kingdom” by the Polish musician Jacaszek creates a potent space, somewhere between dreaming and consciousness.

title: Something (On My Mind)
review: Vancouver producer Jack Jutson wins the 2014 award for "Best Use Of Saxophone (Non-Jazz Category)."

title: High Ball Stepper
review: Jack White unleashes a scorching guitar instrumental that hits you like a rock salt blast to the chest. Try not to sing that otherwordly screamy hook.

title: Lazaretto
review: Jack White brilliantly does what Jack White brilliantly does: quotable posturing, devil-child swagger and a searing solo.

title: Wading Child In The Motherless Water
review: A one-time gospel saxophonist works himself into a trance, mashing up two spirituals through steady accretion and cathartic snatches of melody.

title: El Venao
review: A classic merengue gets reimagined with dark electronic undertones.

title: One, Two...Many
review: This is what honky-tonk drinking songs are supposed to be like.

title: Ain't Misbehavin'
album: All Rise: A Joyful Elegy for Fats Waller

title: We Made It (Remix)
review: Take a Soulja Boy song; twist it with satire and knife sharp social commentary and you’ve got another bold statement from this undervalued artist.

title: AcME (take it to the wall.)
review: Quintuple-threat Jean Grae made a sex song that puts her skills as a comedian and songwriter in particular on blast.

title: Seen It All (feat. Jay-Z)
review: If Michael Mann could make a rap song – high highs, low lows, loud voices making big moves against a creeping sense of dread.

title: Perez Santiago: Glaub
review: An eerie, atmospheric, and deeply compelling duet between cellist Jeffrey Zeigler and composer/electric guitarist Felipe Perez Santiago.

title: Slippery Slopes
review: Indie pop’s best lyricist casts her gimlet eye on rock and roll’s open relationships as the guitars rise behind her like San Fernando Valley mist.

title: Don't Tell 'Em
review: The interpolation of Snap!’s 1992 hit “Rhythm is a Dancer” catches the ear, but the hauntingly spare production and the singer’s impeccable flow keep you listening to this sultry hit.

title: Do I Have The Time
review: The Ohio singer-songwriter bursts out of her former Americana mold with a newfound visceral, blood on the lips fury. The dreamy flanged guitars and gnarled squelches of distortion say it all: this is not at all the same old Jessica Lea Mayfield.

title: Nightmare Sisters
review: You hate to see a soulful Yank outdo a Brit at its own guitar-pop, but Jon Sebastian presents a gorgeously textured song with a chorus that should never end.

title: Schubert: Der Leiermann
review: At the end of a harrowing winter’s journey, beyond the village, you meet an organ grinder, barefoot in the snow. Dogs snarl. Will you follow him?

title: Bellini: Dopo l'oscuro nembo
review: A rarely heard student piece by Bellini makes an opulent platform for today’s most exciting opera singer.

title: Schley
review: The SoCal punk band may have given into its Britpop proclivities to wonderous effect, but, oh, you can't fool us with that careening chorus, yelling the song title at the top of our lungs.

title: Busy Earnin'
review: That riff.

title: Real
review: The Colombian pastel princess of social media intrigue goes the sweet route on this spaced-out, funk-laced tune.

title: Boa Noite
review: This was my Discovery of the Year, thrilled to explore the dense layers of Brazilian and hip hop funkiness on the entire album.

title: Bless The Telephone
review: Kelis has spent much of the past decade looking into the crystal ball of soul, but here revs up a soul revue with some perspective on love lost and lessons learned.

title: Breakfast
review: This calm take on Labi Siffre’s simple love song is the sweet center of Food, the soul singer’s adventurous collaboration with TV on the Radio’s Dave Sitek.

title: i
review: Ever the chameleon, K. Dot threw us all for a loop with this message of self-love, which he boasts over a flip of an Isley Brothers classic.

title: Too Real
review: The winner of this year's Groovy Soca Monarch competition in Trinidad and Tobago is our favorite Soca song of 2014.

title: Homicide
review: Emotional devastation enacted and re-lived over and over – one of the best performed songs of the year.

title: Quarterback
review: The next time someone says current country music is just escapist tripe, play them this: A 21-year-old looks the reality of date rape right in the eye.

title: Philosophize In It ! Chemicalize With It!
review: A frantic, impeccable anthem from an artist whose love of surprise keeps paying off.

title: Cassiopeia (feat. Gregor Schwellenbach)
review: Rune Reilly Kölsch is the reigning king of classy Ibiza anthems. "Cassiopeia" is just his latest perfect sunset.

title: Overdosi
review: One of the best kept secrets of Latin hip hop- this song is thick, slow and hallucinogenic.

title: Strawberry Fields Forever
review: The only remake that works for this song: recast from the persepctive of workers picking strawberries

title: You Go Down Smooth
review: Admit it, this doesn't sound like anything else.

title: She Bangs
review: Best cover of the year, period- the Dominican duo gives Ricky Martin the klezmer makeover he so badly needs

title: Falik: Your Temple, Lord
review: Could this be what heaven sounds like? A silvery-voiced soprano soars above a gently rocking beat from a luminous choir. The ‘gorgeous meter’ just broke 11.

title: All His Saints
review: On this instant classic by Hayes Carll, Womack shows why she's one of current country's great song stylists.

title: Gershwin: The Man I Love
review: Using just five fingers, the 85-year-old pianist still plays like a master, conjuring an orchestra of colors in this left hand only arrangement.

title: Born in Chains
review: The great poet Cohen has said this song took him forty years to write; in its current, “pure gospel” version, it feels truly eternal, the script on a lost scroll.

title: Pretty Girls
review: A non-single in the middle of an LP, Nabuma Rubberband, on which Yukimi and the gang continue their quest for musical identity, "Pretty Girls" is a bona fide mid-tempo R&B gem. (midyear blurb)

title: I'm Gone
review: Pensive and brooding, the young Maryland rapper spits flecks of Kendrick, Drake, Yelawolf and more as he finds his own voice.

title: Past Life
review: The band swaps out its string section for synth-pop flourishes -- a shockingly even trade.

title: Set Me Free
review: The genre-bending, Filipina, one-woman-band manages to pack a lifetime of sounds and epiphanies into 2 minutes and 12 seconds of bliss.

title: Stand Right By Each Other
album: Down Where The Spirit Meets The Bone
review: An update on "Stand By Your Man" that doesn't put all of the onus on the wife. What a concept.

title: Small Window
review: This track opens the most beautiful album of 2014 Passerby with its plaintiff stare out an airplane window and thoughts of what is left behind.

title: Wine Lips
review: Just 24, Loveless channels two or three lifetimes' worth of weary grit into this hooky jam about kissing a lover who's been drinking.

title: Choroq
review: A musical alchemist, and master of both the oud and three-stringed guembri, Bekkas breeds a unique hybrid of Moroccan spiritual trance music and jazz.

title: Dust, Juice, Bones & Hair
review: Humans are mostly bones, liquid and air, as this raucous chorus reminds us, but these British kids take care to emphasize the adverb.

title: Therapy
review: The Queen of Hip-Hop Soul takes a detour across the pond on her new album. The result, heard here, is the refreshing sound of liberation.

title: The First Time
review: Intimate, rainy day musings from another standout in a strong year for singer-songwriters.

title: L.I.P.S.
review: Mélat is a newcomer, but her style brings back memories of the lush '90s R&B soundtrack that so many of us fell in love to.

title: Comet, Come To Me
review: Grounded in a truly tidal reggae rhythm, this meditation on erotic longing from the eclectic boss of the bass is a masterpiece of pop minimalism.

title: Fight Night
review: Migos has an infallible formula: They makes us laugh, dance, and shake our heads as we rap along to lyrics that hardly ever make sense.

title: Bloodlines
review: The more closely you examine this slinky, sinister wonder, the more mysterious and alluring it gets.

title: Bathroom Sink
review: A mundane spot in the house inspires a stormily rocking treatise on self-image.

title: Sunday Hotel
review: If I ever get stuck in a "Groundhog Day" time loop, I'd want this song to be my "I Got You Babe."

title: Pressure
review: This baroque pop gem takes a thrilling drum corps and woodwinds open tacks on a tribal rhythm breakdown and just goes for it. All the way.

title: Handel: Son qual stanco pellegrino
review: Handel proves great beauty exists in sadness. This lament benefits from Stutzmann’s gorgeous contralto and touching accompaniment from a cello piccolo.

title: I Don't Know
review: Consider yourself lucky if you make it to the end of "I Don't Know" without dropping everything and curling up in the fetal position.

title: Jealous
review: He was always the JoBro with the most potential.

title: Am I Wrong
review: Pan-African rhythms meet Scandinavian pop on this bit of summer dreaming from two ambitious polyglots.

title: Tzenni
review: A rollicking, grooving update of griot tradition, with Seymali’s husband, Jeich Ould Chigaly, playing burning-hot guitar licks.

title: Molecule
review: Forget everything you know about rock and hip-hop's unfortunate past together. Lamont "Bim" Thomas is here to scuzz the beat and "get your hands up / shut the hell up."

title: U Guessed It (feat. Key)
review: Screamin’ Jay Hawkins, Howlin’ Wolf, Ol’ Dirty Bastard…OG Maco? This minimalist track by Atlanta’s most extroverted rap eccentric inspired countless parodies on the social media platform Vine and placed him among music’s great oddball shouters.

title: The Riverbed
review: The closest thing the Montreal composer has made to the pop songs he deconstructs so eloquently on his Facebook page.

title: Truck Stop Gospel
review: This 21-year-old Oklahoman comes on like greased lightning in a song that melds John Prine with Carl Perkins, motoring forward on a great fiddle line and kickdrum.

title: Bodies Made Of
review: The guitars have the biting melody of the band Television, so I was immediately hooked and the quirky words made this an unforgettable song in 2014.

title: Pent-Up House (Live At Oslo Jazz Festival / 2008)
Tchaikovsky: June
review: In a calendar’s worth of piano music by Tchaikovsky, June turns wistful, and its melody irresistible in the fingers of a young, emerging Russian pianist.

title: Interference Fits
review: Bruising, scabrous, primitive noise-rock -- but, seriously, Google the inscrutable lyric. Meredith Graves can write the hell out of a song.

title: Queen
review: A bedroom-glam anthem perfect for a political moment in which marriage equality’s new normal vies with the homophobia that still plagues “different” kids everywhere.

title: Gush
review: Pharrell shows no mercy as he seduces on the dirtiest, funkiest track we've heard from him in a while. More of this, please.

title: Slow Motion
review: All sleek charisma, the Wisconsin band makes the subtlest star turn imaginable.

title: Everything Nice
review: In a better world, this would have been the song of the summer.

title: Divinity (feat. Amy Millan)
review: Robinson's hooky, throbbing dance epic chops Amy Millan's vocal into little pieces and isolated phrases, yet still captures all the heartsickness and wonder it seeks.

title: And Breeding
album: Bodies and Control and Money and Power
review: Everything about this topsy-turvy punk barnburner wants to explode until the howling Katie Alice Greer punctures the R&B vamp... that's when the insanity falls into place.

title: CLOUDS
review: “Oh, you kids think you know how to do electrofunk? Step aside and let me school you in Afro-futurism, sex talk and slap bass.”

title: Time 2 Technique
review: While this relentless funky house cut keeps it four on the floor, the D.C. duo is obsessively intent on shifting the percussion with the gorgeous synth lines that woft about like clouds.

title: Come & See
review: this song starts so off kilter rhythmically, but that only sets up the anthemic refrain sung by Detroit’s Joe Casey, “I’ll try to live defeated, come and see the good in everything.” This guitar sounds builds in a way that makes me believe everything Joe says.

title: Lunch Money
review: The beat is "Keys Open Doors" meets "Grindin'," packed into a burbling fishtank. Pusha is Pusha, which is everything.

title: Hey QT
review: I, for one, welcome our sugar-smacked, alien-pop music overlords.

title: Cut Your Bangs
review: One of the stranger lyrical about-faces of the year, in which a hooky guitar-pop song about something so innocuous as a hair cut soon turns morbid in an oddly sweet kind of way.

title: No Flex Zone
review: The song you couldn't escape if you tried. At least now you knowww better.

title: Separate Songs
review: A boisterous and broken arena-rock song with the grand swell of an organ, as it comes up against the failure of a life-that-could-be in a way that hurts.

title: Lifestyle (feat. Young Thug and Rich Homie Quan)
review: A loosey-goosey, sneering irritant of a song with a bottom so round and wide you can’t knock it over. It cuts through everything.

title: Sanctified (feat. Kanye West and Big Sean)
review: Betty Wright. Betty Wright. Betty Wright. Betty Wright. Betty Wright. Really? Me? Too Aggressive?

title: Chemical Plant
album: The Lights From The Chemical Plant
review: A genuinely haunting ballad about young love that turns older in a desolate landscape, it’s inspired by the Texas of troubadour Ellis’s youth, and was recorded in Nashville, but lives up to the legacy of Springsteen’s The River.

title: Little Maggie
review: A brilliant update of an old bluegrass tune, layered with Juldeh Camara’s earthy kologo lute.

title: Nada Em Vão
review: This is how you sound like Brazil while at the same time not sounding like you're from Brazil. Deeply textrued music from a true visionary.

title: Night School
review: One of the quieter moments on The River & the Thread, the string- and acoustic-laced "Night School" proves that less is very often more.

title: Do It Again
review: The Scandinavian dance-pop dream team craft an ode to club life’s endless night that’s glowstick bright but tinged with melancholy.

title: Carousel Ride
review: A big band of brass and more takes us on a spin of a carefree life full of chance and danger. Sung by Kalmia Traver, who has recently battled ovarian cancer, this song takes on a larger meaning as does the album it comes from Survival Sounds.

title: Close Your Eyes (And Count To F---)
review: What does it take to get Rage Against the Machine's Zack De La Rocha on a verse? Make him the incessantly buzzing hook for a bludgeoning track that takes no prisoners.

title: Happy Alone
review: Fueled by the doomstruck rumble of its unlikely instruments, the Ohio band sings the praises of solitude.

title: House Party
review: Nashville songcraft meets Atlanta beats in this boisterous and deeply sweet good-time come-on from the year’s most promising new mainstream country star.

title: Leave Your Lover
review: Some found the melodramatic build of this massive hit (complete with requisite gospel choir) overblown, but the angelic voice at its center made its mournfulness exquisite.

title: Stay With Me
review: The English wunderkind is this year’s breakthrough vocalist, and this spare ballad -- his “Someone Like You” – gives him room to show the color and lushness of that extraordinary voice.

title: Lífsins ólgusjór
review: I was surprised by the strong love of reggae music when I recently visited Iceland. Not to say Samaris is a reggae band, far from it, this band of electronics, clarinet and ethereal vocals do however seem to find inspiration from the great Jamaican melodica player Augustus Pablo.

title: Some People Will Tell You
review: Acoustic singer-songwriter works with Eminem, Raekwon and hip-hop producer S1, then returns with her boldest, most surprising album to date.

title: Brando
review: Masochistic violence meets metallic abyss (and a little Guns 'N Roses) in nine minutes of restrained ridiculousness from these masters of their own brands of heavy.

title: IMF
album: A Long Way To The Beginning
review: Fueled by driving horns and an irresistible beat, Fela's youngest son resurrects his father's zombies as "very dangerous" international bankers.

title: Ishmael
review: Ishmael Butler appeals to the heart of hip-hop in a synth-laden stream of thought: "Sinister hearts ride sinister grooves."

title: Dearly Departed (feat. Esmé Patterson)
review: An old-fashioned rock and roll duet based around super-sexy vocal interplay tumbles into the 21st-century on the energy of its clattering, atmospheric arrangement.

title: On The Regular
review: Cowbells bounce, syths do the worm and a newcomer with something to say throws cartoon shade. Hi, hi, howdy, howdy, hi, hi.

title: Every Time The Sun Comes Up
review: Van Etten's voice gets more confident and powerful with each record -- and it's a perfect match for the slithering, Cure-style guitar line here.

title: Taking Chances
review: Van Etten's voice gets more confident and powerful with each record -- and it's a perfect match for the slithering, Cure-style guitar line here.

title: Loyal (PWRFNK Remix)
review: The Montreal remix extraordinaire improves the biggest R&B song of the year, which feels like an accomplishment

title: What You Want
review: Somewhere between those Nuggets comps you ripped from the library and a rag-tag Thin Lizzy demo lies exactly what you want from this Philly rock 'n' roll band.

title: Chandelier
review: A very tricky song about the grind of alcoholism that manages to also capture the giddy swirl of self-obliteration that makes people drink in the first place

title: How We Be
review: Ahmed Gallab mixes African pop, Curtis Mayfield and existential reassurance on this killer groove of a song.

title: Chasing The Dream
review: These Canadians likely have Riot and Tokyo Blade stiched onto their denim jackets and in their speed-metal loving hearts. Grab a few cases of Coors Light, we need to party until dawn.

title: The River
review: Swampy and funky, this is foot-stomping, hand-clapping goodness that outright dares you to not stomp and clap along.

title: Do You
review: That ever-so-slightly detuned “Do you” descending chromatic melody is one of this year's most-hummable hooks. Then you realize this song is reflecting on taking a chance on love, showing vulnerability and committing to relationships in specific yet economic detail.

title: Rent I Pay
review: After a four-year layoff, the model of brutal rock ‘n’ roll precision sounds more brutally precise than ever.

title: Call Me
review: Blue-eyed soul from the heart of true believers who grew up on the holy ground where this stuff all started, centered around a voice that gathers itself and hits like an Alabama storm.

title: Digital Witness
review: Those funky horns. The gut-rumbling synth bass line. And Annie Clark’s stunning guitar work. All add up to a supremely dance-ready track questioning the role technology plays in shaping our lives this selfie-driven digital age: “If I can't show it if you can't see me? / What's the point of doing anything?” Indeed.

title: Milly's Garden
review: One of the most underrated songwriters working today gives us a potent flashback to vintage Grateful Dead.

title: JM
review: A blistering and heartfelt tribute to Jason Molina from Philadelphia’s Timothy Showalter and his band Strand of Oaks. The guitar line feels straight out of Neil Young’s ‘Cortez the Killer’ something I bet the late Jason Molina would be just fine with.

title: sommeil
review: The irrepressible Belgian artist traffics in a heady blend of EDM, hip-hop, pop and rock in a powerful song whose protagonist has everything… but sleep.

title: Turtles All The Way Down
review: Simpson embraces the classic sounds of outlaw country (Cash, Jennings, Haggard) while forging a path entirely its own.

title: A Little Lost
album: Master Mix: Red Hot + Arthur Russell
review: Reimagining the work of electronic pioneer Arthur Russell, the always-shape-shifting Sufjan delivers an understated yet sonically rich love song of icy industrial textures and warm, unrelenting sweetness.

title: Carissa
review: A plaintive ode on the tragic, horrifying death of his cousin, Mark Kozelek ruminates in the fragility of life and how it never unfolds in the ways we expect. Spare and sad and heartbreakingly lovely.

title: Second Guessing
review: For Sweeney, failure and disappointment are there to place hard-earned happiness in context.

title: Sharabi
review: A rich-voiced British-Indian singer makes an inspired musical masala: layering Afro-jazz with qawwali, alongside duo Rizwan Muazzam.

title: Coffee
review: This song from the duo of Amelia Meath of Mountain Man and producer Nick Sanborn of Megafaun was pleasantly ever-present in 2014. It’s a perfect marriage of organic and inorganic, voice and electronics, old and new including quoting the words of Jeff Barry and Ellie Greenwich and their 60s hit “Hanky Panky”

title: Blank Space
review: In the year's most quotable pop smash (okay, after Beyonce's "Flawless"), Swift steers into the skid that is her endlessly dissected public persona.

title: Out Of The Woods
review: It’s so exciting to see the most accomplished current songwriter in the teen-vernacular vein grow up and figure out how to really use music to express all those emotions, too.

title: Shelter Song
review: This signature song from one of Britain's favorite new bands could easily be mistaken for a deep cut from the Nuggets box set.

title: Heartsmash
review: Under two minutes, the Dublin power-pop band yelps "I've got a heartsmash for you" 16 times with the reckless abandon of The Buzzcocks and The Undertones. Give us 16 more.

title: Not This Time
review: A near-perfect pop song that's destined to become a cult classic. Bonus points for the Michael McDonald coda.

title: Palace
review: I am not sure what I expected from The Antlers, but stately horns and a pretty piano line wasn’t amongst my expectations. Still I’ve come to love the heart and melancholy in this song, a song I found hard not to start all over after its five and half minutes had passed.

title: Weight Of Love
review: The duo kicks off its latest album with an epic jam that includes the longest (and best) guitar solo ever from Dan Auerbach.

title: Milwaukee
review: Aimee Mann's wryness, Ted Leo's live-wire energy, and a walk past a Fonzie statue converge in this crackling pop-rock charmer.

title: Beneath The Brine
review: A six minute suite begins with a foghorn and builds to a feverish and astonishing vocal performance by band leader Liam McCormick. There’s so much power and talent in this young band who boasts an extended family of over several hundred members.

artist: The Ghost Of A Saber Tooth Tiger
title: Too Deep
review: Sean Lennon finally blossoms into a bonafide rock star with the best record of his career. Fantastic grooves and smart riffs.

title: Lullay, I Saw
review: England's marvelous vocal quartet bids farewell with this tender and sweet 15th-century Christmas carol.

title: When I Get My Hands On You
review: Marcus Mumford takes on Bob Dylan in the best way possible and over the simplest arrangement imaginable. And it just works.

title: Brill Bruisers
review: From zero to "unstoppable anthem" in less than one second -- seriously, count it.

title: Kong
review: In one of the year's fizziest, least resistible pop-rock songs, the boyish German band waits for a superman.

title: Black Metal
review: This is a Venom cover, but it sounds like no metal you’ve ever heard. Drew Daniel of electronic experimentalists Matmos deconstructs and reassembles your hesher fantasies.

title: Quiescent
review: An update of the old New York flow -- insistent but gentle horn strapped to a rim shot that walks with a hitch in its step. Two guys suggest you use your melon.

title: Under the Pressure
review: A perfect driving song with atmosphere to spare.

title: Fantasy
review: Alongside lazy horns and slightly off keys, Gouché recalls the sting of relationships just out of our reach, the ones we often want most.

title: Me At The Museum You In The Wintergardens
review: New Zealand's Hollie Fullbrook sings a winsome, wonderful, you-are-there ode to workplace romance.

title: Wild Way
review: This subtle offering from the goddess of majestic piano confessionals starts with the words “I hate you” and unfolds in a thousand emotional directions from there.

title: Habits (Stay High)
review: This percolating pop hit from Sweden’s latest pop auteur wins in the venerable category of happy songs about miserable realities.

title: The Way He Looks At Me
review: Nobody makes textures as original and horrifying as Trent Reznor and Atticus Ross. Grateful for the chill they send down my spine.

title: Seeds
review: Tracking a love affair from first glance to slow dance, showing off the skills of a band of great collaborators

title: High As Hello
review: A sweet surprising project from Jeff Tweedy and his drumming son Spencer. There are 20 good songs on this record, this was my entry point, simply one moment full and rich at others

title: Paranoid (Remix) (Feat. French Montana & Trey Songz)
review: French Montana tags along as R&B's resident bad boys trade verses on the remix for the raunchiest song about paranoia ever made.

title: Feel
review: The best song from the year’s best rock record. Segall has released a staggering amount of music in recent years and it just keeps getting better.

title: PCC
review: The sound of pearly gates, fluffy clouds and soft lighting, brought to you by Kompakt Records' Pop Ambient series.

title: Good Kisser
review: As Mr. Raymond circles back to his roots, he coos over a heavy drum loop, complete with a bottle xylophone. By the time you get to the bridge, you’re grooving too hard to be offended. (midyear blurb)

title: Distant Is The Sun
review: If there isn't a music video for this Australian power-metal ballad, yet, galloping horses towards dusk might be in order.

title: La Burrita (feat. Eddika Organista)
review: Cumbia and wah wah guitar? what's not to like from this young band?

title: Nate
review: The rapper ambivalently picks apart his childhood -- his motivations and impulses, lessons learned and taught -- and yearns for a life that's better than the one he'd once wanted.

title: Cleopatra
album: Everything Will Be Alright In The End
review: The best album they’ve released in 15 years. “Cleopatra” sums all the reasons why: Reflective but bold, and crazy catchy.

title: Wrong Star
review: A convulsing punk song never sounded so gorgeous. White Lung may have been born under a wrong star, but this star explodes with desperate urgency.

title: Wanderlust
review: These synths brood and seethe a quiet storm, moodily building to Hayden Thorpe's devastating kiss-off: "Don't confuse me for someone that gives a f---."

title: The Wall
review: An emblematic ballad for 2014 from The Wise One, about reckoning with the tough stuff.

title: Psycho Animundi
review: Just before the doom-metal band released its third album with Uta Plotkin, the soulful vocalist announced her departure. Her command has never been so majestic as on this bluesy, devastating track.

title: With Light And With Love
review: Every year-end songs list worth its salt has at least one 9-minute psychedelic guitar jam.

title: Deny
review: Cool, sexy and modern textures frame this lithe Lebanese voice, stripped of all the ornaments of traditional Arab pop.

title: Turner: The Bear & The Squirrel
review: The group yMusic, with producer Son Lux, smudge the lines between classical and pop with Jeremy Turner’s yearning lament for winds and strings.

title: Marrow
review: Is there a word for what YOB does in these 19 minutes? It's a psychedelic, doom-metal ballad stretched across the sky, "needing to feel something true." We'll call it "marrowing."

title: Loosey In the Store With Pennies
review: Lyrics for days, in the pocket flow and a comforting sibilance. From a project so good that – to some people -- it was literally unbelievable.

title: Hegemony
review: Could this entire song be the greatest drum fill of 2014?

title: Lost You (feat. Twin Shadow & D'Angelo Lacy)
review: Like you, Zeds Dead and Twin Shadow often want to make late night phone calls they probably shouldn't. Unlike you, they write great songs with killer beats about it.
